about.description: Learn more about the "Look at the Stars" project, our team, and the homemade astronomical observatory. Join us and discover the beauty of space!
about.intro: , and this site is my attempt to tell you about my hobby, bring together all the information, and capture the achievements made on the way to exploring space. Astronomy for me is not just a hobby, but a whole world that changed my life. Thanks to it, I found incredible friends, learned a lot, and realized how vast and mysterious the expanses of the Universe are. This project is our joint contribution to the popularization and development of astronomy. We sincerely believe that thanks to our efforts, space will become closer and more accessible to everyone.
about.observatory-conclusion: This project is our contribution to the popularization of astronomy. We sincerely hope it will inspire you to discover the Universe!
about.observatory-intro: This project is one of the most significant stages of my life. Our homemade astronomical observatory is a unique phenomenon for the Orenburg region. It operates autonomously and allows you to capture images of deep space objects, making astronomy accessible to everyone. More details about the observatory's operation and equipment can be found in the section -
about.observatory-photos-1: Soon we will launch a free telescope control service so that even more people can join the beauty of the night sky. Don't forget to check out the section
about.observatory-photos-2: , where you can find images taken with the observatory and during our stargazing trips. These photos are processed by me and my friends and reflect our passion for space.
about.observatory-work-1: The observatory is open to everyone. Anyone can use its capabilities to obtain images of cosmic objects. Moreover, the site has a section
about.observatory-work-2: , where you will find an archive of FITS files. These data can be used for training, asteroid search, astrophotography, and other scientific or creative purposes.
about.project-description: In 2016, we launched the "Look at the Stars" project in the Orenburg region to make astronomy accessible to everyone. Since then, every season we hold free lectures under the open sky, organize trips out of town with telescopes, and host informal sidewalk astronomy evenings.
about.project-goal: The main goal of the project is to show the greatness and beauty of the Universe, to inspire people to study space. We cover not only the Orenburg region but also neighboring regions, traveling to places where the night sky is especially bright. Learn more about our current and past events on the page
about.project-lectures: One of the most important components of the project are lectures given by experienced amateur astronomers. We talk about scientific discoveries, the history of astronomy, and its modern achievements. The lectures are held in a light format, where complex things are explained in simple and understandable language. This helps listeners not only broaden their horizons but also inspires independent study of astronomy.
about.project-locations: Our events are held not only in cities and towns of the Orenburg region but also in neighboring regions. We organize field trips to remote places where minimal light pollution allows you to fully enjoy the starry sky. Our team of amateur astronomers and volunteers shares their knowledge and experience so that everyone can discover the beauty and mysteries of the Universe.
about.project-sidewalk: , and for those who want to see the stars in the city, we have prepared a section
about.project-sidewalk-astronomy: We pay special attention to sidewalk astronomy evenings. These open-air meetings are held in the most accessible places in the city. At such events, anyone can come, look through a telescope, and learn more about what the starry sky hides.
about.project-sidewalk-link: Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg
about.team-description: We work in various fields, but we are all united by one thing — love for the stars and the night sky. Since 2016, we have been popularizing astronomy, organizing stargazing trips in the Orenburg region and sidewalk astronomy evenings in Orenburg. Together we look at the stars, share knowledge, and inspire others.
about.telegram-channel: Subscribe to the author's Telegram channel of this project
about.title: About
about.your-help-conclusion: Thanks to your help, space really becomes closer!
about.your-help-description: Our homemade observatory project has also found a response among many caring participants. We have ambitious plans for the development of this direction, and your support plays a key role. We are grateful to everyone who helps with advice, consultations, and recommendations. If we accidentally missed someone in the list of thanks, write to us — it is very important.
about.your-help-intro: The development of the "Look at the Stars" project was largely made possible thanks to the support of the "Native Cities" social investment program of Gazprom Neft and the assistance of the Orenburg Media information agency team.

The table includes information about total exposure, processed photos, and data for each filter: Luminance, Red, Green, Blue, Ha, OIII, SII. Learn more about each object and observation details conducted by the observatory.
objects.title: List of astronomical objects

observatory.description: Homemade amateur astronomical observatory with remote access from anywhere in the world via the Internet. Observatory statistics, number of frames taken, and accumulated data. Telescope work calendar.
observatory.description-1: The main activity of the observatory is photographing deep-sky objects such as nebulae, galaxies, and star clusters. The equipment and technologies used in the observatory allow for high-quality images that can be used for scientific research and educational purposes.
observatory.description-2: The observatory operates in semi-automatic mode, allowing remote control from anywhere in the world via the Internet. This makes it accessible to amateur astronomers, researchers, and enthusiasts worldwide.
observatory.description-3: The observatory is open to cooperation with amateur astronomers, researchers, and educational institutions. We are happy to provide access to our data for scientific and educational purposes. If you want to become part of our community or use our resources for your projects, contact us via the feedback form.
observatory.description-4: Orenburg Observatory is a unique combination of modern technology and the enthusiasm of amateur astronomers. We strive to make astronomy accessible to everyone interested in the mysteries of the Universe. Join us to explore the vastness of space together!
observatory.equipment-description: The instruments and technologies used ensure high observation accuracy and professional image quality. Here is the main equipment used:

coma-corrector.description: Eliminates optical distortions, ensuring image clarity.
coma-corrector.title: Coma corrector: Baader 2" Mark III MPCC

filter-wheel.description: Universal filter wheel for working with various spectral ranges.
filter-wheel.title: Filter wheel: ZWO EFW 8x31mm

filters.description: Set of filters for color imaging and narrowband shooting.
filters.title: Filters: ZWO L, R, G, B, Ha, OIII, SII (1.25")

focuser.description: Electronic focuser for precise focus adjustment.
focuser.title: Focuser: ZWO EAF

guide-camera.description: Camera for accurate guiding and tracking of objects.
guide-camera.title: Guide camera: QHY QHY5

guide-scope.description: Compact telescope for guiding during long exposures.
guide-scope.title: Guide scope: SV106 Guide Scope 50mm (Helical Focuser)

main-camera.description: High-sensitivity astronomical camera with 24 MP resolution, capable of capturing the finest details of distant objects.
main-camera.title: Main camera: ASI ZWO 6200MM Pro

mount.description: Reliable and accurate mount, ensuring telescope stability even during long exposures.
mount.title: Mount: Sky-Watcher EQ6

telescope.description: Reflector telescope with a 200 mm aperture, ideal for deep-sky observations.
telescope.title: Telescope: Sky-Watcher BK2001P

observatory.text: Observing the Universe starts here - in real time you can see current weather conditions, camera streams, equipment status, and shooting schedule. The observatory operates in semi-automatic mode, allowing remote deep-sky shooting. An intelligent control system analyzes weather conditions and automatically decides when to start work. Learn more about the equipment and operation principle on a separate page:
observatory.title: Observatory

observatory-weather.description: Current weather charts from the amateur observatory's weather station near Orenburg. Temperature, humidity, cloudiness, and wind speed in real time.
observatory-weather.title: Weather at Orenburg Observatory

photo.description: {{photoTitle}} - photo of an astronomical object taken at the homemade observatory, equipment used: {{equipment}}.

photos.description: A collection of astrophotographs of galaxies, star clusters, nebulae, planets, and other cosmic objects captured by the amateur observatory. Find and filter images by category and parameters to see unique shots of the Universe with details for each filter and exposure.
photos.title: Astrophotos

star-map.description: Star map with galaxies, nebulae, comets, supernovae, and other cosmic objects captured by an amateur telescope
star-map.text-part-1: The star map is an interactive window into the Universe, featuring images of galaxies, nebulae, comets, supernovae, and other astronomical objects. These images were obtained with an amateur telescope, making them especially valuable: they show what beauties of space are available even outside professional observatories.
star-map.text-part-2: The map allows you to study the night sky in detail, track the movement of celestial bodies, and find interesting objects for observation. Thanks to quality astrophotography and systematic catalog updates, every visitor can see space as astronomy enthusiasts around the world see it.
star-map.title: Star map

stargazing.description: Stargazing trip in Orenburg — exciting trips out of town where telescopes open cosmic horizons. Evenings of scientific discoveries, lectures, and live communication with like-minded people. Learn the rules and prepare for star observation.
stargazing.telegram-subscription: To not miss announcements - subscribe to the Telegram channel
stargazing.text-part-1: Stargazing trip in Orenburg is an opportunity to touch the mysteries of the Universe, observing the starry sky in complete darkness. We invite you to exciting trips out of town, where telescopes open cosmic horizons right in the fields of Orenburg.
stargazing.text-part-2: Each stargazing trip is an evening of scientific discoveries, inspiring lectures, and live communication with like-minded people. You will learn how our events are held, get acquainted with the main rules of stargazing trips, and be able to prepare in advance for star observation.
stargazing.title: Stargazing trips
stargazing.where_link: Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg

stargazing-faq.description: Find answers to frequently asked questions about stargazing trips: registration, what to bring, cost, duration, and how to get there. Prepare for a night under the stars with comfort!

cancel.answer: Just cancel your booking using the previous link. Free slots will appear on the site and people will be able to register.
cancel.question: ❓I registered but can't go. What should I do?

duration.answer: On average, the official program from the start of the lecture to telescope observations lasts 2 hours. But for you, they will fly by unnoticed, guaranteed. After that, you choose whether to stay and watch the sky with telescopes or go home. Approximate end time: 00:30.
duration.question: ❓How long does a stargazing trip last?

feedback.answer: In all social networks, our group is called "Look at the Stars". We value feedback and always read your reviews. Thank you for them!
feedback.question: ❓Where can I leave a review?

kids.answer: Yes, absolutely! We are very happy when the younger generation is interested in science! But the recommended age is from 6 years. Trust our experience.
kids.question: ❓Can children attend?

late-registration.answer: No, sorry. Our rules are the same for everyone. We introduced the registration system for a reason and monitor entry to the astro site.
late-registration.question: ❓Registration is closed and I didn't make it. Can I come? Please!

merch.answer: We bring hoodies, t-shirts, car stickers, postcards, and sticker packs to the astro field. Want to support the project? Buy our merch!
merch.question: ❓How and where to buy your merch?

more-people.answer: No, you can't. Our rules are the same for everyone. The number of people allowed on the site by QR code is the number you registered. No exceptions.
more-people.question: ❓I registered 1/2/3/4/5 people, can I bring more?

no-car.answer: We do not organize transport or transfers. Our task is to organize a great event, yours is to get there. For your convenience, we created a chat
no-car.answer2: . Join, meet people, and find company. Everyone there is cool, sociable, and reliable. Want to chat about space? Join the themed
no-car.question: ❓I don't have a car, what should I do?

photo.answer: Of course! You can take photos, but please follow etiquette rules so as not to disturb other participants. Do not use bright flashes or lights, as this can spoil night observation.
photo.question: ❓Can I take photos?

price.answer: All our stargazing trips are free. The project grows and develops, and we are always happy for support from listeners and subscribers. For this, there are
price.answer2: . Want to support us? We will be grateful!
price.question: ❓How much does it cost?

public-transport.answer: Unfortunately, no. The venue is far from public transport routes. You can get there by your own car or join other participants if they are willing to take you. We recommend arranging this in advance via our Telegram channel.
public-transport.question: ❓Can I get to the stargazing trip by public transport?

qr.answer: QR code is your entry ticket to our event. It will be checked at the entrance. Please prepare it in advance to avoid traffic jams on site. If you don't have a QR code, we will have to refuse you. The QR code is our way to regulate the number of participants at the stargazing site. Our natural landscape and the team's physical capabilities have limits. Please respect this and understand.
qr.question: ❓Why do I need a QR code?

registration.answer: No, you can't. Registration is required as it allows us to plan the event, notify participants of possible changes, and ensure comfort for everyone.
registration.question: ❓Can I come without registration?

start-time.answer: Each stargazing trip announcement has a specific start time. This time it's 21:30. Guest gathering on the site is announced from 20:00 to 21:00. This means we ask you to arrive early — listen to music, take photos with the Moon and sunflowers, watch sunsets, breathe the steppe air. And importantly, park your car and avoid traffic jams. We really appreciate it!
start-time.question: ❓What time does it start?

support.answer2: . We constantly buy equipment, update technical capabilities, create merch and various activities. Your support is ❤︎❤︎❤︎
support.question: ❓I like you! How can I support you?

telescopes.answer: No, you don't have to bring your own telescope. We always have several telescopes for general use. If you have your own instrument, you can bring it, and our experts will help you set up and use it.
telescopes.question: ❓Do I need to bring my own telescope?

weather.answer: If the weather forecast is unfavorable (clouds or precipitation), the event may be canceled or postponed. We always notify participants of such changes via our Telegram channel, so be sure to follow updates.
weather.question: ❓What if it's cloudy or rainy?

what-to-bring.answer: For a comfortable stay at the astro site, be sure to bring warm clothes (we're in the steppe, it's windy and cold at night), a camping mat, folding chairs, blankets. We also recommend thermoses with tea/coffee and sandwiches. Take insect repellent. Hookahs, barbecues, alcohol, cigarettes are prohibited! And we have the cleanest site. After the stargazing trip, we don't find a single wrapper or piece of paper and thank you very much for that!
what-to-bring.question: ❓What should I bring?

where.answer: Our stargazing trips are always held out of town. Usually within 40-70 km. We leave the city lights to see the stars. The exact location is available after registration. If you lost the location, return to the registration page using the same link. There is geolocation - Yandex.Map and Google.Map.
where.question: ❓How do I find out where it is?

stargazing-faq.title: Frequently asked questions

stargazing-howto.arrival_text: Arrive 15–20 minutes before the start to get a comfortable spot on the astronomy field. Bring folding chairs or mats for comfort.
stargazing-howto.description: Learn how stargazing trips in Orenburg work: registration, lectures about space, telescope observations, and learning to navigate the starry sky. Subscribe to the "Look at the Stars" Telegram channel and join unique astronomy events under the starry sky!
stargazing-howto.event_announcement_text: Stargazing trips in Orenburg are held in good weather, so the exact date is known only 2-3 days before the event. We announce upcoming trips in our "Look at the Stars" Telegram channel, where we post announcements and important updates. Subscription to the channel is required so you don't miss a new stargazing trip.
stargazing-howto.event_duration_text: The entire stargazing trip lasts from 2 to 4 hours. You can leave the site at any time, but many stay until the end, enjoying the views of the starry sky.
stargazing-howto.faq: Didn't find the answer to your question? Check the section
stargazing-howto.lecture_text: As soon as dusk falls, our astro lecture begins. On the big screen, we show videos and photos, talking about space in an accessible and interesting way. Lecture topics vary: from "Perseid Meteor Shower" to "What do Black Holes Hide". Lectures are for participants from 8 years old and last about an hour.
stargazing-howto.location_text: Stargazing trips are held out of town, away from city lights, usually 40 km from Orenburg. The exact location will be revealed after registration. You need to get to the field on your own, so check the route in advance. The last section of the road is a dirt road about 300 meters long.
stargazing-howto.orientation_text: After the lecture, we teach you to find the main stars and constellations, showing them in the sky. This part lasts about 20 minutes.
stargazing-howto.recommendations_text: Please read the "Stargazing trip rules" section to make the event comfortable and safe for everyone.
stargazing-howto.registration_text: Participation requires prior registration on our website. It's free and takes just one minute. Note: beware of scammers, if someone asks for payment for participation — it's a scam! We welcome donations, but participation is always free.
stargazing-howto.telegram: or write in our Telegram channel
stargazing-howto.telescope_observation_text: Several telescopes are installed on the astronomy field, each aimed at specific cosmic objects. You can look through the telescopes, ask questions, and talk to astronomers.
stargazing-howto.thematic_evenings_text: Sometimes we hold sidewalk astronomy right in the city. Read more about such events in the "Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg" section.
stargazing-howto.title: How stargazing trips work
stargazing-howto.unique_event: Each stargazing trip is unique, but we follow a general scenario to make the event interesting and convenient for all participants.

stargazing-rules.description: Learn the rules of stargazing trips in Orenburg: what not to do when observing stars and planets through a telescope. Follow the recommendations to make the trip safe and comfortable for everyone.
stargazing-rules.importance-description: Following these recommendations helps make star observation in Orenburg as comfortable as possible for everyone. We create an atmosphere where each participant can see amazing celestial phenomena, study planets through a telescope, and get an unforgettable experience.
stargazing-rules.importance-title: Why is it important to follow the rules?
stargazing-rules.join-description: Want to learn more about our events organized in Orenburg?

prohibited-items-1.description: Flashlights, phone screens, and any bright light sources disrupt eye adaptation to darkness, reducing star visibility. Use only red flashlights or special light filters for devices.
prohibited-items-1.title: Use bright light sources

prohibited-items-2.description: Stargazing trips are held in fields and open areas where there is a high risk of fire. Lighting fires is strictly prohibited.
prohibited-items-2.title: Light fires and use open flames

prohibited-items-3.description: Alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, e-cigarettes, vapes, and hookahs are prohibited. This is not only a fire safety issue but also respect for other participants, for whom clean night sky and fresh air are important.
prohibited-items-3.title: Drink alcohol and smoke

prohibited-items-4.description: Loud music, shouting, or other sharp sounds can distract and interfere with concentration when observing through a telescope. Respect the silence and mood of others.
prohibited-items-4.title: Make noise and disturb other participants

stargazing-rules.prohibited-title: What not to do on stargazing trips

recommendations-items-1.description: Take all your trash with you after observation. We try to leave stargazing sites as clean as they were before our arrival.
recommendations-items-1.title: Protect nature

recommendations-items-2.description: Move carefully to avoid damaging equipment and injuring yourself.
recommendations-items-2.title: Follow safety rules

recommendations-items-3.description: Everyone comes to stargazing trips to enjoy the beauty of space. Respectful attitude towards each other makes the atmosphere friendly and comfortable.
recommendations-items-3.title: Respect other participants

stargazing-rules.title: Stargazing trip rules
stargazing-rules.welcome: Welcome to stargazing trips in Orenburg, organized by the "Look at the Stars" project! To make joint observation of the starry sky and planets comfortable and safe for everyone, it is important to follow a few simple rules. These recommendations help preserve the atmosphere of night observation and ensure that everyone can enjoy the view of stars and planets through a telescope.

stargazing-where.announcement-1: Announcements of sidewalk astronomy evenings are almost always published in our
stargazing-where.announcement-2: , but sometimes you can find our telescopes on the city streets without warning. One of the project inspirers, astro lecturer Vladimir Ivanovich, often shares his knowledge, showing interesting astronomical objects to everyone. Just look for a telescope — and you will definitely get an unforgettable excursion through the starry sky!
stargazing-where.description: Find out where in Orenburg you can look through a telescope. Sidewalk astronomy: free observations of the Moon, planets, and stars on city streets. Want to see more — go out of town to observe nebulae and galaxies!
stargazing-where.title: Where to look through a telescope in Orenburg
stargazing-where.want-to-see-description-1: To observe faint objects such as the Orion Nebula, Andromeda, meteor showers, and star clusters, you need to go far from city lights. In places like the Orenburg steppe or other remote areas, the night sky is stunningly beautiful.
stargazing-where.want-to-see-description-2: We regularly organize field astronomy events where you can enjoy the full palette of cosmic objects. Follow announcements on our "Stargazing trips" page or in the Telegram channel to join one of these observations.
stargazing-where.want-to-see-more: Want to see more? Go out of town!
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-1: Craters and mountains on the Moon, especially impressive in the first and last quarter phases;
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-3: Bright stars and double stars, such as Albireo;
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-4: Planet parades, if they occur at the right time of year.
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-conclusion: However, city lighting limits our possibilities. Nebulae, galaxies, meteor showers, and even large star clusters often remain hidden from view.
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-description: In conditions of city light pollution, the brightest objects remain visible. For example, you can see:
stargazing-where.what-you-can-see-title: What can you see through a telescope from the city?
